intro: Pseudolysimachion incanum, commonly known as the silverleaf sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit and grayish-white foliage that reflects sunlight, aiding in its survival in hot, dry environments. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in the spring. Its stems and leaves are covered in fine, white hairs, which contribute to its silvery appearance and help reduce water loss. Pseudolysimachion incanum is adapted to sandy soils and is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats.
